context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: White House, EPA reportedly blocked embarrassing pollution report
context_meta.summary: It's not the nation's most recognizable federal office: the Department of Health and Human Services' Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR). Nevertheless, earlier this year, the agency put together a report of great significance – which you didn't hear about for a reason. Federal officials uncovered a water-contamination crisis affecting several areas, with toxic chemicals reaching water supplies near military bases, chemical plants, and other sites in the Mid-Atlantic and Midwest. Common sense suggests officials would learn of these finding and think, “Quick, let's take action to address the problem.” Trump administration officials, however, apparently thought, “Quick, let's

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Is the Ring of Fire more active with volcanoes, earthquakes than usual?
context_meta.summary: Reports of earthquakes and volcano eruptions in regions along the Ring of Fire might lead some to believe that the level of activity in recent months is above average.

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Are electric cars worse for the environment?
context_meta.summary: All those V8s, V6s and turbocharged vehicles we've grown to love will soon be replaced by squadrons of clean, whisper-quiet, all-electric vehicles. Policymakers at every level have done their part to push electric vehicles by creating a tankful of subsidies. Thanks to laws signed by both George W. Bush and Barack Obama, electric-vehicle buyers can feast on federal tax credits of up to $7,500 that reduce the initial purchase cost of their vehicles. Not to be outdone, many states also dangle their own mix of goodies for electric vehicle buyers, including purchase rebates as large as $5,000, additional rebates for vehicle chargers, and free use of public charging stations—which, of course, are only “free” because they're subsidized by ratepayers and taxpayers.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: No time to waste: Moscow urged to recycle, not burn
context_meta.summary: Protests have been growing in recent months over the stench from landfill sites around Moscow, overflowing with millions of tonnes of rubbish. Authorities have now decided on a plan to tackle the problem -- generating energy by burning the waste instead. Russia produces almost 70 million tonnes of rubbish per year, according to Greenpeace's estimates.

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Arctic oil 'undrillable' amid global warming: U.N.'s ex-climate chief
context_meta.summary: By Alister Doyle OSLO (Reuters) - An architect of the Paris climate agreement urged governments on Tuesday to halt oil exploration in the Arctic, saying drilling was not economical and warming threatened the environmentally fragile region. Christiana Figueres, formerly head of the U.N. Climate Change Secretariat when the Paris accord was reached by almost 200 nations in 2015, told Reuters by telephone "the Arctic has been rendered undrillable." The past three years have been the hottest since records began in the 19th century, and Figueres said the heat was a threat to everything from Australia's Great Barrier Reef to ice in Antarctica. The former Costa Rican diplomat who campaigns for a peak in global emissions by 2020 said it made no economic sense to explore in the Arctic, partly because it was likely to take years to develop any finds.

context_meta.title: Why a 100-year-old Indian company is investing billions into renewable energy
context_meta.summary: Tata Power, one of India’s largest thermal power companies, is making a $5 billion (around Rs33,263 crore) bet on the country’s renewable energy sector. Over the next decade, the 103-year old company plans to quadruple its clean energy capacity, taking it from around 3,417 megawatts (MW) now to around 12,000 MW. The company currently has…

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Earthquake jolts San Francisco Bay Area
context_meta.summary: OAKLAND, Calif. The Latest on an earthquake that rattled the San Francisco Bay Area (all times local): 10:05 p.m. A small earthquake that rattled the San Francisco Bay Area didn't cause any major damage or injuries but it did delay commuter trains and a baseball game. The U.S. Geological Survey says a 3.5-magnitude temblor struck two miles (3 kilometers) northeast of Oakland at 7:18 p.m. Monday. Bay Area Rapid Transit says tracks were inspected after the quake, which caused a 10-minute systemwide delay. The San Francisco Chronicle reports that the quake briefly interrupted the San Francisco Giants game. The quake was felt as far away as Petaluma, about 40 miles northwest of Oakland. 8:04 p.m.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Colorado rangers kill bear suspected of mauling child
context_meta.summary: Wildlife rangers in Colorado on Monday shot and killed a black bear suspected of attacking and trying to drag off a five-year-old girl from her yard. "When she went outside to investigate, she witnessed a large black bear dragging her ... daughter," the Colorado Parks and Wildlife agency said in a statement. Wildlife agents set up traps and deployed tracking hounds in an effort to locate the bear, said Mike Porras, a spokesman for the state parks agency's northwest region office.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Caged tiger at Florida school's prom causes uproar
context_meta.summary: The prom theme was “Welcome to the Jungle” for students at Christopher Columbus High School in Miami-Dade, but a caged menagerie — that included a tiger — was too much for some people, according to news reports. Friday night's prom at the Double Tree Hilton Miami Airport Convention Center featured the tiger and several other animals — and also included fire dancers dressed in animal costumes, WPLG-Ch. 10 reported. Marie-Christine Castellanos, whose brother was at the prom, took to social media to criticize the event calling it “shameful” that exotic animals were used for entertainment. “Tigers are wild animals. They don't need to be displayed as objects for our amusement. They don't like the

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Highway 17 roadkill solution coming in 2021
context_meta.summary: SANTA CRUZ- Three years from now, people driving on Highway 17 can expect to see construction on Laurel Curve — not a road widening or a curve correction but a new bridge designed to save the lives of mountain lions and deer crossing the road and reduce costly and injurious collisions with wildlife. The Caltrans solution, estimated to cost $12 million, has morphed in five years from a tunnel to “the most optimal design,” a 60-foot roadway bridge with an undercrossing to give large animals safe passage, according to Nancy Siepel, a Caltrans biologist. A major commuter route, Highway 17 sees about 61,500 vehicles a day locally, according to Caltrans, and there are no culverts where animals might cross. Laurel Curve was selected because this is where a majority of mountain lions roaming to the Diablo Range and the Gabilan Mountains cross Highway 17, according to data from the Santa Cruz Puma Project, a UC Santa Cruz study that began in 2008.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Exposing Indoor Air Quality: Monitoring And Energy Efficiency Are Helping
context_meta.summary: US Environmental Protection Agency workers don protective gear at 110 Liberty St to test cleaning methods as part of the EPA's indoor clean air initiative for Lower Manhattan, New York, New York, June 27, 2002. Some have walkie-talkies and others are bringing air quality monitors into the building.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: 4 earthquakes recorded near central Oklahoma town
context_meta.summary: CRESCENT, Okla. –  A series of earthquakes has been recorded near the central Oklahoma town of Crescent. The U.S. Geological Survey says four earthquakes struck Sunday night through Monday morning, all near Crescent, about 35 miles (55 kilometers) north of Oklahoma City. The quakes had magnitudes ranging from 2.5 to 4.1. There are no reports of injuries or damage. Many of the thousands of earthquakes in Oklahoma in recent years have been linked to the underground injection of wastewater from oil and natural gas production. State regulators have directed several producers to close or reduce volumes in some wells. Scientists say the threshold for damage usually starts at 4.0. The strongest earthquake

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: German police bring in crane to get 5 buffalo off autobahn
context_meta.summary: BERLIN (AP) — Police called in a crane to lift five fugitive water buffalo off a highway in western Germany during an operation that lasted about nine hours.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Moment Cornwall shark attack victim is airlifted to hospital after he was bitten on the leg
context_meta.summary: These are the horrific wounds suffered by a fisherman who was airlifted to a hospital after he was bitten on the leg by a close relative of the Great White shark on a fishing boat off the coast of Cornwall. Max Berryman, 21, who is said to have experienced a 10-inch shark bite down his leg muscle, was taken to the Royal Cornwall Hospital in Truro by a coastguard rescue helicopter on Sunday morning. The young angler, from Penzance, suffered leg injuries when a porbeagle shark was brought on deck in the trawler's nets and the crew was attempting to release it back into the water. But the young fisherman is just happy that the wounds aren't any nearer to his groin.  Max said: 'It had me in its jaws

context_meta.title: 7-foot alligator that was 'ticked off' and hissing gets stuck on Lowcountry porch
context_meta.summary: A North Charleston family woke up Monday morning to an unwelcome guest knocking on their front door: A confused 7-foot alligator had taken up residence on their porch. And although the alligator was missing one if its front legs, it was still hissing and was strong enough to have broken out a section of porch railings. Louise Monteith, who lives with her husband Charles and their three children on Waltham Road, heard the banging around 4:30 a.m. Monday. She said she blamed her three dogs and three cats for the noise and went back to sleep. Her husband, though, got up to investigate, she said. He opened the blinds, and that's when he saw the alligator. "He came running back upstairs cursing up

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Powerful storms kill at least 43 across northern India
context_meta.summary: Powerful winds and rainstorms swept across a crowded swath of northern India, demolishing houses, uprooting trees and killing at least 43 people as winds turned the skies brown with dust and sand, officials said Monday. Most of the deaths occurred when wind and falling trees caused buildings to collapse, leaving people buried in the wreckage. In the town of Bareilly, the minaret of a mosque fell on a group of people taking shelter in the courtyard, killing eight people. In another town, one man was killed when he was hit by a billboard that had been blown loose. Less than two weeks ago, similar storms caused 134 deaths and injured another 400. The extreme weather comes amid withering summer heat,

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: The ‘killer scorpions’ and poisonous frogs being mailed to China to feed exotic pet craze
context_meta.summary: Exotic animals including ‘killer scorpions’ and poisonous frogs are being mailed into China alive in regular parcels to feed a boom in owning alternative pets. The influx of banned insects and animals - which also include snakes, spiders, beetles and tortoises - has prompted fears that the new arrivals could harm China's biodiversity and farming output, or even be used by terrorists. Illicit traffickers evade customs inspectors by only packing small amounts of live animals each time, but the overall trade has been described as "rampant" by Chinese media. Authorities have issued warnings against importers and enforced tighter border controls in response to the trade, which has also caused alarm among animal rights groups. More than 42,000 mail and parcel deliveries of banned animals and plants were seized at Chinese ports last year, and harmful species were identified in 5,147 of them, China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine said. Chinese pet owners are driving a boom in illicit imports of everything from scorpions to beatles A statement posted on the China Quality news website, which is affiliated to the organisation, added: "They may have no natural enemies in China, so they will likely reproduce in great numbers and pose a serious threat to indigenous species and harm China's ecology, biodiversity and agricultural production if they are not properly taken care of." Customs officials also identified that some species, such as the Brazilian “killer scorpion”, poison dart frogs and poisonous snakes, could be dangerous to the public, or even be "used by terrorists", the China Daily said. Pet owning was banned in China under revolutionary leader Mao Tze-tung, who believed it was a bourgeoisie hobby. But the rise in urbanisation and Western trends has seen dogs and cats being welcomed into many homes. Families often lavish huge amounts of cash on their pets in China, where there are pet hotels, pet cemeteries and even facilities for pet acupuncture. However, Chinese animal lovers are now becoming more adventurous in the species they want to own. Reports in China suggest there is a growing trend for monkeys, foxes and reptiles being traded in China. Pa Chongle, a store run at South China Agricultural University which breeds lizards and snakes, generates 20,000 yuan (£2,300) a month through sales, student Li Yiqun said. "A lizard costs from 100 to 600 yuan (£12- 70) and a snake from 250 to 800 yuan (£29-93) and we usually sell them when they are a month old," Mr Li told The Telegraph. He said most of the animals at Pa Chongle, which roughly translates to 'Crawl Lovers', are sold to "young white collar workers". The cross-border trade in animals is tightly regulated under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), which China has signed. Animal welfare activists say the illegal transportation of animals can be brutal and cause massive harm to the eco-system where the animal was taken from. Sun Quanhui, from World Animal Protection, said: "Driven by Chinese demand for having wild animals as pets, each year tens of thousands of wild animals are forced to leave their natural habitat areas and become victims of the wild animal trade. "These animals are mistreated repeatedly during the capture, transportation and trade process. Batches have died, and those which are lucky enough to survive have lost their freedom and have no way back to their natural habitat." Wendy Higgins, from the Humane Society International, said animals endured "stress, malnutrition, dehydration, and long periods of confinement" during the transportation. "And for those who do survive, their suffering can continue as a pet because most people have no idea how to provide the complex environmental or dietary needs of these animals," Ms Higgins added. "Exotic wild animals belong in the wild where they can thrive in the freedom of their natural environment. Their home is not in our home." Despite the legal and ethical concerns over cross-border trading of wild animals, The Telegraph found many foreign species being sold openly on the Chinese Internet, including turtles from Brazil, Arctic foxes from the "North Pole" and widow spiders from Laos. The spider dealer offered to mail the arachnid from his store in Ningbo, in China's east, to Beijing, within three days, once payment of 90 yuan (£10.50) was received. "They are definitely from Laos because there are no males in China, so reproduction is impossible," the dealer told The Telegraph. When asked how he got the spider into China, he said: "We have our own sources". Additional reporting by Christine Wei

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Colorado girl seriously injured in bear attack outside home, officials say
context_meta.summary: A 5-year-old girl was seriously injured early Sunday morning after a bear attacked her outside her Colorado home when she went to investigate a noise in the yard, officials said. The girl went outside around 2:30 a.m. after hearing noises in the yard in East Orchard Mesa, above the Colorado River corridor in Grand Junction, she thought was her dog, FOX31 Denver reported. He mother told Colorado Parks and Wildlife officials she heard her daughter scream and saw a large black bear dragging the girl. The bear dropped the 5-year-old when the mother began screaming at the animal, according to the report. The girl was taken to the hospital with serious injuries. Officials are still tracking the animal

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Mysterious hairy 'globster' washes up on a beach. It's being called an omen of doom.
context_meta.summary: A giant, foul smelling "globster sea creature" has washed up in the Philippines, leading frightened villagers to vow it is a sign of doom, reported news outlets such as the British tabloid, the Sun. The big, hairy carcass showed up May 11 on a beach near the town of San Antonio in the Oriental Mindoro province, according to multiple media outlets. Early coverage has appeared in the same types of media outlets that cover ghost and alien abductions. However, National Geographic acknowledged some similar mysterious "hairy blob" discoveries last year, suggesting the find isn't a hoax. The Sunday Express summed up a less scientific perspective Saturday under the headline: “BAD OMEN as 20ft SEA MONSTER
